title: Number of Germans Owning Stocks Soars 44% in Last Decade
description: As the German stock market booms for a third year, racking up gains of more than 20% in 2025, the number of Germans who own equities is up 44% from a decade ago, and the assets in exchange-traded funds have soared an estimated 200% since 2017 to €343 billion ($400 billion), industry data show. Bloomberg's Isolde MacDonogh reports. (Source: Bloomberg)
content: Germany? No, not really known for its share of mom and pop investors, for retail investors. But things are starting are starting to change. The DAX is up 20% year to date. And I think I think those memories, you know, they continue. And Germans have always been, you know, very, very good savers, you know, instead of taking more risk.
summary: The number of Germans investing in stocks has risen by 44% in the last decade. The DAX is up 20% year to date and has been outperformed by the past two years. Investors are gravitating towards safer investments in German equities, with ETFs seen as being particularly popular. Concerns about the pension system are also cited as a key factor in this trend. An 82-year-old investor, who had previously complained about German people being too cautious about investing in stock, sensed a change and felt it was looking up.
shortSummary: Germany's stock market surged 44% in recent years, driven by record-breaking gains, but concerns over pensions and economic stability remain persist.
argos_summary: Germany is witnessing a shift in retail investment, with the DAX index up 20% year to date, attracting around 3 million new investors in the past three years. Concerns about the pension system's sustainability are driving individuals to seek safer investment options like ETFs. This change in attitude is also influenced by social media, which is reaching younger audiences and encouraging a more proactive approach to investing.
